\\end{matrix}]`),mdx("p",null,"This formula may look familiar \u2013 we derived an identical expression when we were discussing the power requirement of a moving car."),mdx("p",null,"What\u2019s a typical wind speed? On a windy day, a cyclist really notices the wind direction; if the wind is behind you, you can go much faster than normal; the speed of such a wind is therefore comparable to the typical speed of the cyclist, which is, let\u2019s say, 21 km per hour (13 miles per hour, or 6 metres per second). In Cambridge, the wind is only occasionally this big. On a breezy day, this windmill was producing 60 kW, (1400 kWh per day). Photo by Philip Banks.",mdx("p",null,"The density of air is about 1.3 kg per m",mdx("sup",null,"3"),". (I usually round this to 1 kg per m",mdx("sup",null,"3"),", which is easier to remember, although I haven\u2019t done so here.) Then the typical power of the wind per square metre of hoop is"),mdx("p",null,`[\\begin{matrix}
{\\frac{1}{2}\\rho v^{3} = \\frac{1}{2} \\times \\text{1.3\\ kg/}\\text{m}^{\\text{3}} \\times \\left( \\text{6\\ m/s} \\right)^{\\text{3}} = \\text{140\\ W/}\\text{m}^{\\text{2}}} `,"\\",`
\\end{matrix}]`),mdx("p",null,"Not all of this energy can be extracted by a windmill. The windmill slows the air down quite a lot, but it has to leave the air with ",mdx("em",{parentName:"p"},"some")," kinetic energy, otherwise that slowed-down air would get in the way. Figure B.2 is a cartoon of the actual flow past a windmill. The maximum fraction of the incoming energy that can be extracted by a disc-like windmill was worked out by a German physicist called Albert Betz ",mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"#chBn01"}),mdx("span",{class:"darkred"},"[1]"))," in 1919. If the departing wind speed is one third of the arriving wind speed, the power extracted is 16/27 of the total power in the wind. 16/27 is 0.59. In practice let\u2019s guess that a windmill might be 50% efficient. In fact, real windmills are designed with particular wind speeds in mind; if the wind speed is significantly greater than the turbine\u2019s ideal speed, it has to be switched off."),mdx("p",null,"As an example, let\u2019s assume a diameter of ",mdx("em",{parentName:"p"},"d")," = 25m, and a hub height of 32 m, which is roughly the size of the lone windmill above the city of Wellington, New Zealand (figure B.3). The power of a single windmill is"),mdx("p",null,`[\\begin{matrix}
`,"\\",`
{= \\text{50\\%} \\times \\frac{1}{2}\\rho v^{3} \\times \\frac{1}{4}\\pi d^{2}} `,"\\",`
{= \\text{50\\%} \\times \\text{140\\ W/m}^{\\text{2}} \\times \\frac{1}{4}\\pi\\left( \\text{25\\ m} \\right)^{2}} `,"\\",`
{= \\text{34\\ kW}} `,"\\",`
\\end{matrix}]`),mdx("p",null,"Indeed, when I visited this windmill on a very breezy day, its meter showed it was generating 60 kW."),mdx("p",null,"To estimate how much power we can get from wind, we need to decide how big our windmills are going to be, and how close together we can pack them."),mdx("p",null,"How densely could such windmills be packed? Too close and the upwind ones will cast wind-shadows on the downwind ones. Experts say that windmills can\u2019t be spaced closer than 5 times their diameter without losing significant power. At this spacing, the ",mdx("span",{id:"power"},"power")," that windmills can generate per unit land area is"),mdx("p",null,`[\\begin{matrix}

{= 0.016 \\times 140\\text{W/m}^{\\text{2}}} `,"\\",`

(Remember, wind power scales as wind-speed cubed.)"),mdx("p",null,mdx("img",e({parentName:"p"},{src:"/img/without-hot-air/figure261.gif",alt:null}))),mdx("span",{class:"figurenumber"},"Figure B.6.")," Average summer windspeed (dark bar) and average winter windspeed (light bar) in eight locations around Britain. Speeds were measured at the standard weatherman\u2019s height of 10 metres. Averages are over the period 1971\u20132000.",mdx("p",null,"On the other hand, to estimate the typical power, we shouldn\u2019t take the mean wind speed and cube it; rather, we should find the mean cube of the windspeed. The average of the cube is bigger than the cube of the average. But if we start getting into these details, things get even more complicated, because real wind turbines don\u2019t actually deliver a power proportional to wind-speed cubed. Rather, they typically have just a range of wind-speeds within which they deliver the ideal power; at higher or lower speeds real wind turbines deliver less than the ideal power."),mdx("h3",e({},{id:"variation-of-wind-speed-with-height"}),"Variation of wind speed with height"),mdx("p",null,mdx("img",e({parentName:"p"},{src:"/img/without-hot-air/figure266.gif",alt:null}))),mdx("span",{class:"figurenumber"},"Figure B.7.")," Top: Two models of wind speed and wind power as a function of height. Not a typical windmill.",mdx("h3",e({},{id:"standard-windmill-properties"}),"Standard windmill properties"),mdx("p",null,"The typical windmill of today has a rotor diameter of around 54 metres centred at a height of 80 metres; such a machine has a \u201Ccapacity\u201D of 1 MW. Usually, wind turbines are designed to start running at wind speeds somewhere around 3 to 5 m/s and to stop if the wind speed reaches gale speeds of 25 m/s. ",mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"#chBn02"}),mdx("span",{class:"darkred"},"[2]"))," The actual average power delivered is the \u201Ccapacity\u201D multiplied by a factor that describes the fraction of the time that wind conditions are near optimal. This factor, sometimes called the \u201Cload factor\u201D or \u201Ccapacity factor,\u201D depends on the site; a typical load factor for a good site in the UK is 30%. ",mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"#chBn03"}),mdx("span",{class:"darkred"},"[3]"))," In the Netherlands, the typical load factor is 22%; in Germany, it is 19%."),mdx("h3",e({},{id:"other-peoples-estimates-of-wind-farm-power-per-unit-area"}),"Other people\u2019s estimates of wind farm power per unit area"),mdx("p",null,"In the government\u2019s study [",mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"http://www.world-nuclear.org/policy/DTI-PIU.pdf"}),mdx("span",{class:"websitetitle"},"www.world-nuclear.org/policy/DTI-PIU.pdf")),"] the UK onshore wind resource is estimated using an assumed wind farm power per unit area of at most 9 W/m",mdx("sup",null,"2")," (capacity, not average production).
